questions.text: A 50-year-old man who has worked in the glass manufacturing industry for over 20 years presents with progressive dyspnea, a chronic dry cough, and fatigue. On examination, he has bilateral crackles on auscultation. A high-resolution CT scan reveals a crazy-paving pattern in the lungs. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Silicosis

Explanation:

Silicosis is the most likely cause, given the patient’s long history of working in the glass manufacturing industry, exposing him to silica dust.

Silicosis:

  • Leading cause of Interstitial lung disease (ILD) in India, frequently resulting from occupational exposure in the glassware, mining, quarrying, and construction industries.
  • Manifests after 10-20 years of continuous exposure.
  • Radiological features:
    • The chest radiograph may show profuse military infiltration or consolidation, and there is a characteristic HRCT pattern known as “crazy paving”.
    • Multiple well-circumscribed 3–5 mm nodular opacities predominantly in the mid-and upper zones.
    • Enlargement of the hilar glands with an “egg-shell” pattern of calcification (seen in 20% of cases).
    • As the disease progresses, progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) may develop.

 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Option A): Inhalation of various organic antigens can trigger a widespread immune complex reaction in the walls of the alveoli and bronchioles. Common causes include conditions like farmer’s lung and bird fancier’s lung. The pathology of hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) involves both type III and type IV immune mechanisms.

 

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (Option B): It is defined as a progressive fibrosing interstitial pneumonia of unknown cause, occurring in older adults. Chest X-ray reveals typically small lung volumes with reticulonodular shadowing but may be normal in early or limited disease. HRCT shows combinations of ground glass changes, reticulonodular shadowing, honeycomb cysts and traction bronchiectasis, depending on the stage of disease.

 

Asbestosis (Option C): Asbestos exposure commonly occurs during activities like demolition work, ship breaking, and the manufacturing of fireproof insulating materials. Characteristic pathological features include pleural plaques, diffuse pleural thickening, acute benign pleurisy, carcinoma of lung, interstitial fibrosis, mesothelioma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of working in mining for over 20 years presents with chronic cough, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Chest X-ray reveals nodular opacities, primarily in the upper lobes. Which of the following complications is he at an increased risk of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tuberculosis

Explanation:

The given clinical presentation is suggestive of Silicosis, a form of pneumoconiosis caused by the inhalation of silica dust, and is associated with an increased risk of developing tuberculosis (TB).

Silicosis

  • Leading cause of Interstitial lung disease (ILD) in India, frequently resulting from occupational exposure in the glassware, mining, quarrying, and construction industries.
  • Manifests after 10-20 years of continuous exposure.
  • Radiological features:
    • The chest radiograph may show profuse miliary infiltration or consolidation, and there is a characteristic HRCT pattern known as “crazy paving”.
    • Multiple well-circumscribed 3–5 mm nodular opacities predominantly in the mid- and upper zones.
    • Enlargement of the hilar glands with an “egg-shell” pattern of calcification (seen in 20% of cases).
    • As the disease progresses, progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) may develop.
  • Individuals with silicosis are at increased risk of TB (silicotuberculosis), lung cancer and COPD; associations with renal and connective tissue disease have also been found.

 

Pulmonary embolism (Option A): It is usually associated with immobility, surgery, or hypercoagulable states, not occupational lung diseases. While anyone can develop PE, silicosis does not specifically increase the risk for PE.

 

Pneumothorax (Option B): It is more commonly associated with diseases like emphysema, tuberculosis, or cystic lung diseases, especially when there’s alveolar rupture. Silicosis doesn't commonly cause pneumothorax, so this is not a typical complication.

 

Pleural effusion (Option D): While it can occur with various lung diseases, they are not a classic feature or complication of silicosis. Unless there's an underlying infection or malignancy, effusions are uncommon in this context.

questions.text: A 70-year-old retired shipyard worker presents with exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough. Pulmonary function tests reveal a restrictive pattern. Which of the following radiographic findings is most characteristic of asbestosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bilateral pleural plaques

Explanation:

Workers in the shipbuilding and construction trades, including pipe fitters and boilermakers, are occupationally exposed to asbestos.

  • Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung.
  • Past exposure to asbestos is specifically indicated by pleural plaques on chest radiographs, which are characterized by either thickening or calcification along the parietal pleura, particularly along the lower lung fields.
  • Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.
  • Complications include carcinoma of lung and mesothelioma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a long history of smoking presents with worsening dyspnea and a recent diagnosis of lung cancer. A lung biopsy reveals changes consistent with interstitial lung disease. Which type of ILD is most commonly associated with smoking?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

Explanation:

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare disorder caused by Langerhans cell proliferation, leading to lung involvement, especially in smokers.
  • It commonly affects young males with cystic and nodular abnormalities in the upper lobes. Lesions extend to broncho-vascular structures, forming characteristic stellate lesions, and there is an increased risk of spontaneous pneumothorax.

Other Conditions Causing Smoking Related ILD

Type

HRCT findings

Respiratory bronchiolitis with ILD (RB-ILD)
  • Central and peripheral bronchial wall thickening, centrilobular nodules, and ground-glass opacities.

Desquamative interstitial pneumonia ( DIP)
  • Bilateral symmetric ground-glass opacities are often more pronounced with other similar findings of RB-ILD.
  • This can also occur in children with a family history of fibrosis.

 

Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (Option A) is a rare lung disease primarily affecting women of childbearing age, characterised by cystic changes on HRCT; however, it is not usually associated with smoking. Spontaneous pneumothorax can also develop in this condition.

 

Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonitis (Option B) is often linked to autoimmune disorders or infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, rather than smoking. It is a diagnosis of exclusion in AIDS patients with shortness of breath.

 

Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis (Option C) involves surfactant accumulation in the alveoli, impairing clearance and causing airway obstruction. Chest X-rays often show a "bat wing" appearance. It can be associated with autoimmune diseases, secondary conditions, or toxin exposure but is not primarily linked to smoking.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with worsening asthma, shortness of breath, and wheezing. She has a history of recurrent sinusitis and recent purpuric skin lesions on her legs. Lab tests show eosinophilia and positive p-ANCA. A chest CT reveals ground-glass opacities and lower lobe consolidation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Churg Strauss Syndrome

Explanation:

  • Churg Strauss Syndrome, called Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EG), is a small-medium vessel vasculitis.
  • It often presents with respiratory symptoms like chronic sinusitis, asthma, peripheral eosinophilia, and positive perinuclear ANCA antibodies.
  • Imaging reveals peripheral consolidative opacities (can be migratory) and small pleural effusions in the lungs.
  • It is an example of granulomatous vasculitis causing ILD; another example is Wegener Granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis).

Wegener Granulomatosis (Option A)

  • It commonly affects the ear, nose, throat, and kidneys, presenting with upper respiratory symptoms, pulmonary nodules, and renal dysfunction (glomerulonephritis).
  • Imaging often shows nodules, ground-glass opacities, consolidations (sometimes migratory), and hilar lymphadenopathy.
  • Hemoptysis is a common feature, as seen in both Wegener's granulomatosis (c-ANCA positive) and Churg-Strauss syndrome (p-ANCA positive), which also involves multiple organs.

Sarcoidosis (Option B):

  • It is a granulomatous lung disease without vasculitis.
  • It is an inflammatory condition marked by granuloma formation, primarily affecting the lungs but sometimes involving the eyes or skin.
  • It typically presents with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary infiltrates, causing cough and dyspnea.


Hypersensitivity pneumonia (Option C)

  • It is caused by an immune reaction to inhaled triggers such as barn hay (Farmer's lung), sugar cane dust (Bagassosis), or cotton dust (Byssinosis).
  • It involves an immune response to inhaled organic antigens, forming granulomas in the lung tissue (granulomatous lung disease).
  • Symptoms resolve when the trigger is removed, but repeated exposure can lead to pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents with worsening dyspnea on exertion and a dry cough. Examination reveals finger clubbing. Which findings might be observed during an interstitial lung disease (ILD) evaluation?


	Wheeze
	Inspiratory crackles
	Dullness to percussion
	Pigeon Breeder's Lung
	Increased tactile fremitus
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1,2,4

Explanation:

Clinical signs and symptoms of ILD

Common symptoms
  • Shortness of breath
  • Dry cough

Haemoptysis
  • Rarely seen
  • It is associated mostly with granulomatous vasculitis

Pleuritic pain

Seen in asbestosis.

Pigeon Breeder's Lung

Seen in occupational history and hypersensitivity pneumonitis

Fever with arthralgia

Seen in Sarcoidosis

Examination Findings
  • Bilateral inspiratory crackles are heard at the base of the lungs
  • Wheeze can be appreciated in conditions like sarcoidosis, Hypersensitivity pneumonitis and Churg Strauss Syndrome.
  • Clubbing
  • Cyanosis
  • Cor pulmonale
  • Raynaud's phenomenon in connective tissue disorder
  • Erythema nodosum in sarcoidosis

 

Dullness to percussion (Statement 3) occurs due to increased density or fluid in the lung or pleural space, disrupting normal resonance. While associated with pleural effusion, consolidation, or masses, it is generally not seen in interstitial lung disease, which involves thickening and scarring of lung tissue rather than fluid accumulation.

 

Increased tactile fremitus (Statement 5) is not true because tactile fremitus is usually decreased in ILD due to thickened interstitial tissue and reduced lung compliance, leading to impaired vibration conduction.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a 6-week history of cough, dyspnea, fever, and fatigue. Respiratory examination reveals inspiratory rales and pulmonary function tests reveal restrictive lung features. HRCT of the thorax shows patchy subpleural consolidative opacities with a ground-glass appearance and a reversed halo sign. A lung biopsy shows a uniform appearance of granulation tissue within the alveolar sac. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cryptogenic organising pneumonia

Explanation:

The patient's subacute clinical presentation, HRCT findings, and lung biopsy showing granulation tissue within alveolar sacs indicate Cryptogenic organising pneumonia.

Cryptogenic Organising Pneumonia

Clinical features

  • Patients are usually 50-60 years of age
  • Subacute onset with symptoms like cough, fever, malaise, fatigue and dyspnea.
  • Respiratory examination: Inspiratory rales

Investigations
  • Pulmonary function tests: Restrictive lung deficits + hypoxemia
  • HRCT thorax
    • Patchy subpleural consolidative opacities
    • Localised ground glass opacities
    • Reversed halo sign - rim of subpleural sparing
Halo Sign" data-author="" data-hash="9531" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/d85q8jf9FWIObz0ERsrT1744388836.png" />
  • HPE: Patchy region of organising pneumonia with the uniform appearance of granulation tissue

Treatment

  • Corticosteroid therapy for 6 months
  • Alternative therapy
    • Mycophenolate
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Rituximab

 

Atypical pneumonia (Option A) is caused by Mycoplasma, Chlamydia, and Legionella, with an insidious onset and non-specific symptoms like fever, headache, dry cough, myalgia, and malaise. Chest imaging may show diffuse or patchy infiltrates, but the reversed halo sign is absent.

 

Interstitial pulmonary fibrosis (Option C) is a chronic, progressive, non-reversible lung disease characterised by fibrosis and scarring of the lung parenchyma. It presents with exertional dyspnea and a chronic dry cough. HRCT reveals reticular opacities, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis, particularly in the lung bases. Histopathology shows interstitial fibrosis.

 

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (Option D) is a life-threatening lung condition triggered by severe infections, trauma, or systemic insults. It presents with sudden respiratory failure and hypoxemia. Chest imaging typically shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates or ground-glass opacities.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of smoking presents with progressively worsening dyspnea and a non-productive cough for the past 6 months. HRCT findings, including subpleural reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis, suggest idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pirfenidone + Nintedanib

Explanation:

Pirfenidone + Nintedanib, an antifibrotic therapy used to slow the decline in pulmonary function, is the treatment of choice in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

Management of Interstitial lung disease

Disease

Treatment

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

Pirfenidone + Nintedanib (Option B)

Nonspecific interstitial pneumonitis

Prednisolone + cyclophosphamide or rituximab (Option C)

Desquamative interstitial pneumonitis

Corticosteroids (Option A) or

Cytotoxic agents (Azathioprine)

Bronchodilators may be used

Cryptogenic organising pneumonia

Corticosteroids

Cyclophosphamide or Rituximab can be used alternatively

Hamman-Rich syndrome

Mechanical ventilation

Lung transplantation (Option D) was once the only treatment option for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). However, with recent advances, antifibrotic therapy is now considered the first-line treatment for IPF.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of progressive dyspnea and a chronic dry cough is being evaluated for suspected interstitial lung disease (ILD). She denies any history of smoking or exposure to environmental toxins. Physical examination reveals fine bibasilar inspiratory crackles. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fiberoptic bronchoscopy with cryo biopsy

Explanation:

Fiberoptic bronchoscopy with cryo biopsy is the choice of investigation for confirmation of interstitial lung disease.

Interstitial Lung Disease

Clinical findings

  • Chest auscultation
    • End inspiratory fine crackles (Bibasilar)
    • Wheezing in case of sarcoidosis
  • Digital clubbing
  • Pedal oedema (if cor pulmonale present)
  • Cyanosis may be present

Investigations

Chest X-ray

  • Hilar lymphadenopathy may present in sarcoidosis
  • Basilar reticular opacities seen in asbestosis

HRCT (Option D)

  • Subpleural reticular opacities
  • Traction bronchiectasis (airway distortion) due to lung fibrosis
  • Reverse halo sign in Cryptogenic organising pneumonia
  • Helps select the location for biopsy
  • Can suggest the type and degree of lung pathology but cannot confirm it.

Pulmonary Function Tests

  • Helps differentiate between obstructive and restrictive lung disease but cannot confirm the diagnosis of interstitial lung disease (Option A)
  • TLC reduced
  • FEV1/FVC is normal or elevated
  • Restrictive pattern
  • Obstructive pattern may be seen in sarcoidosis due to hilar lymphadenopathy.

Biopsy

  • Fiberoptic bronchoscopy
    • With Cryobiopsy: Investigation of choice to confirm diagnosis (Option C)
    • With Bronchoalveolar lavage: can be helpful for cellular examination (Option B)
  • Transbronchial biopsy can also be done, but cryo biopsy is preferred

Autoimmune panel helps identify the underlying cause.

  • Anti-CCP: Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Anti Jol Ab: Dermatomyositis

questions.text: A 59-year-old man presents with recurrent cough, dyspnea, and fatigue for 8 months. His occupation as a bird breeder with exposure to bird droppings suggests hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Pulmonary function testing (PFT) reveals a restrictive pattern. Which of the following disorders should be considered in the differential diagnosis based on the PFT restrictive pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Idiopathic interstitial pneumonia

Explanation:

Idiopathic interstitial pneumonia shows a restrictive pattern on PFT similar to hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

Disorder

Pulmonary Function Test

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

  • Restrictive pattern
  • Total lung capacity ↓
  • FEV1/FVC is normal or ↑

Idiopathic interstitial pneumonia

(Option B)
  • Initially
    • Only diffusion is impaired; thus, DLCO is reduced
    • Normal FVC and FEV
  • As diseases progresses
    • Restrictive pattern
    • Total lung capacity ↓ due to lung fibrosis
    • FEV1/FVC is normal, or ↑ a reduction in FVC is proportionally greater than a fall in FEV1.

COPD (Option A)
  • Obstructive pattern.
  • Total lung capacity ↑ due to trapping of air - lung hyperinflation.
  • FEV1/FVC ↓ due to significant air outflow obstruction.

Bronchiectasis (Option D)
  • Obstructive pattern.
  • Total lung capacity ↑ is due to the trapping of air.
  • FEV1/FVC ↓ due to significant air outflow obstruction due to mucus plugging.

Asthma (Option C)
  • Obstructive pattern
  • Total lung capacity ↑ due to trapping of air
  • FEV1/FVC ↓ due to significant air outflow obstruction
  • Peak expiratory flow rate ↓
  • It is reversible with bronchodilator use

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with worsening shortness of breath and cough, producing copious sputum containing gelatinous material. Laboratory tests reveal no evidence of infectious processes. The physician suspects pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Which mechanism is most responsible for her condition?

choices.text: Deficiency of surfactant proteins due to genetic mutation
Autoimmune response leading to GM-CSF blockade
Exposure to silica dust causing alveolar damage

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Autoimmune response leading to GM-CSF blockade

Explanation:

In pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP), autoantibodies against GM-CSF impair the function of alveolar macrophages, preventing them from clearing surfactant and leading to its accumulation in the lungs, resulting in the patient’s symptoms.

Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis (PAP):

  • It is characterised by impaired function of pulmonary macrophages, primarily due to deficiencies in granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) signalling caused by autoantibodies against GM-CSF leading to the accumulation of surfactant in the alveolar and bronchiolar spaces.
  • Types: (Similar histological changes)
    • Autoimmune PAP: (90% of cases)
      • It primarily affects adults without familial predisposition.
      • Caused by autoantibodies that neutralise GM-CSF function
      • The lack of GM-CSF signalling hinders the maturation of alveolar macrophages, impairing surfactant clearance.
    • Secondary PAP: Rare and associated with various conditions, including:
      • Hematopoietic disorders
      • Malignancies and Immunodeficiencies
      • Lysinuric protein intolerance
      • Acute silicosis and other inhalational syndromes
    • Congenital PAP: Extremely rare and typically seen in neonates
  • Clinical Features:
    • Cough & copious sputum containing gelatinous material.
    • Intermittent febrile episodes due to secondary pulmonary infections
    • Progressive dyspnea, cyanosis and respiratory insufficiency can develop
  • Radiography:
    • Chest x-ray shows bilateral alveolar opacities in a peri-hilar and basilar distribution without air-bronchograms, referred to as a “batwing distribution,” or may resemble pulmonary edema without cardiomegaly or pleural effusions.
    • CT scan reveals intralobular thickening and diffuse ground-glass opacities, often referred to as “crazy paving.”

 

Deficiency of surfactant proteins due to genetic mutation (Option A): This mechanism is seen in congenital forms of PAP, typically presenting in neonates or infants, not adults. While surfactant protein gene mutations can lead to similar pathology, this is not the usual cause in a 50-year-old adult, making it an unlikely explanation here.

 

Exposure to silica dust causing alveolar damage (Option C): Silica exposure is associated with silicosis, not PAP. However, secondary PAP can occur due to inhalational exposures, but it’s much less common than autoimmune causes. There's no occupational exposure history mentioned here, so this is less likely.

 

Allergic reaction to environmental pollutants (Option D): While pollutants can contribute to airway inflammation or asthma, they do not cause PAP. PAP is not an allergic process but rather a surfactant clearance disorder, so this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with progressive dyspnea and a chronic cough with gelatinous sputum. Pulmonary function tests show a restrictive pattern and a normal FEV1/FVC ratio. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral patchy opacifications and a high-resolution CT shows a crazy paving pattern with no signs of infection. What is the most characteristic finding of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Positive Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) staining

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario, with patchy opacifications, a crazy paving pattern, restrictive findings, and a cough with gelatinous sputum without signs of infection, most probably indicates Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis.
  • The most characteristic finding is positive PAS staining, which indicates the presence of surfactant components in the alveolar spaces.

Findings:

  • Pulmonary function tests: Restrictive pattern, FEV1/FVC - Normal/Increased.
  • Chest X-ray: Bilateral patchy asymmetric pulmonary opacifications (Ground glass opacity) and diffuse bilateral shadowing, often more pronounced in the hilar regions
  • HRCT: Crazy pavement pattern (thickened interlobular septa)

Crazy paving pattern." data-author="" data-hash="9519" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/Xrs00AqMq8vzYoIC3D671744388230.png" />

  • Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) Staining: Positive for the alveolar precipitates, indicating the presence of surfactant components.
  • Lung size and weight: Increased due to surfactant accumulation.
  • Ultrastructural analysis: Normal surfactant lamellae in type II pneumocytes, distinguishing PAP from other surfactant dysfunction disorders.

Treatment:

  • Whole-lung lavage is the standard treatment and can be beneficial regardless of the underlying cause.
  • GM-CSF therapy is effective in over half of autoimmune PAP cases.
  • GM-CSF replacement therapy is used for congenital forms, sometimes followed by allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, which may be curative.

Increased neutrophilic infiltration (Option A) is more characteristic of acute inflammatory processes, such as infections, than PAP, which typically shows a minimal inflammatory response.

Granuloma formation (Option C) indicates conditions like sarcoidosis or infections like TB and is not a feature of PAP.

Honeycombing fibrosis (Option D) is associated with advanced interstitial lung diseases, such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, rather than the surfactant accumulation seen in PAP.
